# Circadian Rhythms Article

This article blew my mind. Turns out our circadian rhythms control way more than just sleep:

- **Metabolism** - when we digest food most efficiently
- **Hormone production** - cortisol peaks in the morning, melatonin at night
- **Body temperature** - varies throughout the day
- **Cognitive performance** - peak times for different types of tasks

## Key Insights

Your body has an internal clock that runs on roughly a 24-hour cycle. Light is the primary signal that keeps it synchronized, but eating and exercise also play roles.

### Practical Applications

- Get **morning sunlight** to anchor your circadian rhythm
- Avoid **bright light** (especially blue light) before bed
- Eat your **largest meal** earlier in the day
- **Exercise** at consistent times

The article explains why jet lag is so brutal—you're fighting against millions of years of evolution.

Worth bookmarking for later reference.

# Coffee Brewing Guide

Found this incredibly detailed guide to pour-over coffee. The author is clearly obsessed (in a good way).

## The Basics

Pour-over coffee is all about **control**:

1. Water temperature (195-205°F)
2. Grind size (medium-fine)
3. Pour rate and pattern
4. Coffee-to-water ratio

The guide breaks down each variable and explains how it affects extraction.

### Equipment Needed

- Pour-over dripper (V60, Chemex, etc.)
- Gooseneck kettle
- Burr grinder
- Scale
- Timer

## The Technique

The article describes a **three-pour method**:

1. **Bloom** - wet grounds, wait 30-45 seconds
2. **Main pour** - slow, circular motions
3. **Final pour** - finish to desired weight

Total brew time should be 2.5-3.5 minutes.

- Longhand only (no typing)

- Don't read what you wrote

- My mind feels clearer throughout the day

# Film Recommendation: Past Lives

Watched this last night and I'm still thinking about it. It's a Korean-American film about childhood friends who reconnect as adults after 20 years.

## Why It Works

The film is *quiet*—long silences, lingering shots, minimal dialogue. But every frame is packed with emotion. It's about:

- The sliding doors moments of life
- Paths not taken
- Connection across time and distance
- The immigrant experience
- "In-yun" (인연) - the Korean concept of fate bringing people together

### The Performances

All three leads are phenomenal, but **Greta Lee** carries this film. She communicates so much with just her face—the weight of choices made and unmade.

## Themes I'm Still Processing

- What do we owe to our past selves?
- Can you have multiple "right" people?
- How do we reconcile who we were with who we became?

Not an action-packed film, but it will **wreck you** emotionally. Bring tissues.

**Rating:** 5/5 - Will be thinking about this one for a long time.

# Why I Finally Deleted Social Media

Three months ago, I deleted Instagram, Twitter, and Facebook from my phone. A month later, I deleted the accounts entirely. Here's why I did it—and what happened next.

## The Breaking Point

It wasn't one dramatic moment. It was the accumulated weight of thousands of small moments:

- Reaching for my phone the instant I felt bored
- Scrolling through Instagram while talking to my partner
- Feeling inadequate after seeing everyone's highlight reels
- Losing entire evenings to mindless scrolling
- Checking notifications obsessively throughout the day

One morning, I woke up and immediately opened Instagram *before even getting out of bed*. That's when I realized: **I had a problem.**

> "I'll miss out on important updates from friends"

The friends who matter know how to reach me.

> "I'll be disconnected from current events"

### Week 3-4: Adjustment
- Started reading books again

Social media isn't inherently evil, but the business model is toxic. These platforms are *designed* to be addictive. They profit from your attention, and they're very good at taking it.

- **The world didn't end** when I logged off

I was worried about losing professional connections, but it turned out fine. I:

- Updated my website with contact information

# Lessons from Learning Pottery at 35

Six months ago, I walked into a pottery studio for the first time. I'd never touched clay before, never used a pottery wheel, and had no idea what I was doing. Today, I have a shelf full of wonky bowls and mugs—and I've learned more than just how to center clay.

## Why Pottery?

Honestly, it was random. I saw a "[beginner pottery class](https://example.com/pottery)" poster at a coffee shop and signed up on impulse. I was looking for a creative outlet that didn't involve screens, and pottery seemed... different.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

## Lesson 1: Failure Is Part of the Process

My first attempt at throwing a bowl collapsed into a sad, lopsided mess within thirty seconds. My second attempt wasn't much better. Neither was my tenth.

In pottery, you fail *constantly*. Clay collapses. Rims crack. Handles break off. Pieces explode in the kiln. But here's the thing: **every failure teaches you something**.

### What Pottery Taught Me About Failure:

- Failure isn't personal—it's data
- You learn more from failures than successes
- The goal isn't perfection; it's improvement
- Starting over is often faster than trying to fix mistakes

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur.

## Lesson 2: Patience Is a Skill, Not a Personality Trait

I am not a patient person. I want results *now*. But pottery doesn't work that way.

After throwing a pot, you must:

1. Let it dry to leather-hard (1-2 days)
2. Trim and refine it
3. Let it dry completely (3-5 days)
4. Bisque fire it (8-10 hours)
5. Glaze it
6. Glaze fire it (8-10 hours)
7. Wait for the kiln to cool (12+ hours)

From start to finish, a simple mug takes **two weeks minimum**. You cannot rush it. The clay doesn't care about your deadline.

## Lesson 3: The Process Matters More Than the Product

I used to be obsessed with outcomes. If something didn't turn out perfectly, I considered it a waste of time. Pottery has slowly rewired that thinking.

*The process* of centering clay, feeling it take shape under your hands, solving problems as they arise—that's where the value is. The finished mug is just a bonus.

## Lesson 4: Comparison Kills Joy

In my pottery class, there's a woman who's been throwing for twenty years. Her pots are gorgeous—thin-walled, perfectly symmetrical, with elegant handles. When I first started, I couldn't help comparing my work to hers.

Then my instructor said something that stuck with me: *"The only comparison that matters is between you today and you last month."*

Now I keep my first wonky bowl on my desk as a reminder of how far I've come.

## Lesson 5: Mastery Takes Time (And That's Okay)

Pottery has given me a new appreciation for mastery. I watch experienced potters throw a bowl in five minutes—something that takes me thirty minutes and multiple attempts. That gap used to frustrate me.

Now I see it as exciting. I have *years* of growth ahead of me. Every session at the wheel, I get a little better. The journey toward mastery is long, and that's what makes it worthwhile.

# Managing Morning Anxiety

For years, I'd wake up with my heart racing and a knot in my stomach. Before I even opened my eyes, anxiety was already sitting on my chest, making demands.

If you experience morning anxiety, you're not alone. Here's what's helped me.

## Understanding Morning Anxiety

**Cortisol** (the stress hormone) naturally peaks in the morning—it's what wakes us up. But for some people, this spike triggers anxiety symptoms:

- Racing thoughts
- Physical tension
- Sense of dread
- Difficulty getting out of bed

For me, it felt like waking up *already behind*, like I'd forgotten something important even though nothing was actually wrong.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.

## What Didn't Work

Before I found strategies that helped, I tried things that made it worse:

- Immediately checking my phone (hello, information overload)
- Lying in bed ruminating (amplifies anxious thoughts)
- Caffeinating heavily (more stress hormones)
- Rushing through my morning (validates the "behind" feeling)

## What Actually Helps

### 1. The 5-Minute Rule

I don't *have* to feel better immediately. I just have to get through the next five minutes. Usually, anxiety peaks within 10-15 minutes of waking, then naturally subsides. Knowing this helps me ride it out.

### 2. Physical Grounding

The moment I wake up, I do a **body scan**:

- Notice where tension lives (jaw, shoulders, stomach)
- Take five deep breaths
- Stretch or do gentle movement

This interrupts the anxious thought spiral by anchoring me in my body.

### 3. Morning Pages

I write three pages of stream-of-consciousness thoughts. This *externalizes* the anxiety instead of letting it loop in my head. I don't read what I wrote—it's just a brain dump.

### 4. No Phone for the First Hour

This was hard at first, but it's been transformative. My anxiety feeds on information and urgency. The first hour of my day now belongs to *me*, not to the world's demands.

### 5. Predictable Routine

I do the same things every morning:

- Wake at the same time
- Drink water
- Write morning pages
- Meditate for 10 minutes
- Make breakfast

The predictability is calming. My nervous system knows what to expect.

## Progress, Not Perfection

Some mornings I still wake up anxious. But now:

- I *expect* it might happen
- I have tools to manage it
- I know it will pass
- I don't panic about panicking

The difference between now and two years ago is night and day. Morning anxiety doesn't control my life anymore.

## When to Seek Help

If morning anxiety is severe or persistent, **talk to a therapist**. These strategies have helped me, but they're not a substitute for professional support. There's no shame in needing help—I've been in therapy for years.

## Final Thoughts

You don't have to wake up dreading the day. With the right strategies and support, mornings can become peaceful instead of panic-inducing.

# A Weekend Guide to Lisbon

Lisbon surprised me. I expected beautiful architecture and good food—and it delivered on both—but I wasn't prepared for how *charming* this city is. The hills, the trams, the tiles, the melancholy *fado* music drifting from restaurant windows at night.

## Day 1: Historic Neighborhoods

### Morning: Alfama District

Start in **Alfama**, Lisbon's oldest neighborhood. Get lost (intentionally) in the narrow cobblestone streets. Key spots:

- São Jorge Castle for panoramic views
- Miradouro de Santa Luzia viewpoint
- National Pantheon

1. Praça do Comércio - grand waterfront square
2. Rua Augusta - pedestrian shopping street
3. Elevador de Santa Justa - iconic lift with city views

### Evening: Bairro Alto

**Bairro Alto** comes alive at night. Have dinner at a traditional Portuguese restaurant (I recommend trying *bacalhau*—salted cod), then bar hop through the neighborhood's tiny establishments.

## Day 2: Belém and Beyond

### Morning: Belém

Take the tram to **Belém** along the river. Must-sees:

- Jerónimos Monastery (UNESCO World Heritage site)
- Belém Tower
- Padrão dos Descobrimentos (Monument to the Discoveries)

**Important**: Stop at Pastéis de Belém for the original *pastel de nata* (custard tart). There will be a line. It's worth it.

### Afternoon: LX Factory

Head to **LX Factory**, a hipster creative space in an old industrial complex. Great for:

- Shopping for Portuguese design
- Lunch at trendy cafés
- Instagram-worthy bookstores

### Evening: Sunset at Miradouro

End your trip watching sunset from one of Lisbon's many **miradouros** (viewpoints). My favorite: Miradouro da Senhora do Monte. Bring wine and snacks.

## Practical Tips

- Lisbon is *hilly*—wear comfortable shoes
- Trams and metro are easy to use
- Learn basic Portuguese phrases (locals appreciate the effort)
- Many places are cash-only
- Summer gets hot—bring sunscreen

## What I Learned

Lisbon has a beautiful melancholy to it—especially in the *fado* music and the way locals talk about *saudade* (a uniquely Portuguese word for nostalgic longing). It's a city that looks both backward and forward, honoring its maritime history while embracing modern creativity.

Evening: Bairro Alto

Bairro Alto comes alive at night. Have dinner at a traditional Portuguese restaurant (I recommend trying bacalhau—salted cod), then bar hop through the neighborhood’s tiny establishments.

Day 2: Belém and Beyond

Morning: Belém

Take the tram to Belém along the river. Must-sees:

  • Jerónimos Monastery (UNESCO World Heritage site)
  • Belém Tower
  • Padrão dos Descobrimentos (Monument to the Discoveries)

Important: Stop at Pastéis de Belém for the original pastel de nata (custard tart). There will be a line. It’s worth it.

Afternoon: LX Factory

Head to LX Factory, a hipster creative space in an old industrial complex. Great for:

  • Shopping for Portuguese design
  • Lunch at trendy cafés
  • Instagram-worthy bookstores

Evening: Sunset at Miradouro

End your trip watching sunset from one of Lisbon’s many miradouros (viewpoints). My favorite: Miradouro da Senhora do Monte. Bring wine and snacks.

Practical Tips

  • Lisbon is hilly—wear comfortable shoes
  • Trams and metro are easy to use
  • Learn basic Portuguese phrases (locals appreciate the effort)
  • Many places are cash-only
  • Summer gets hot—bring sunscreen

What I Learned

Lisbon has a beautiful melancholy to it—especially in the fado music and the way locals talk about saudade (a uniquely Portuguese word for nostalgic longing). It’s a city that looks both backward and forward, honoring its maritime history while embracing modern creativity.

Would I go back? Absolutely. Two days barely scratched the surface.
